thread.title: 3-mile long Euclid Creek Tunnel completed; will prevent sewage from flowing into Lake Erie
thread.title_full: 3-mile long Euclid Creek Tunnel completed; will prevent sewage from flowing into Lake Erie | cleveland.com

author: James F. McCarty, The Plain Dealer
title: 3-mile long Euclid Creek Tunnel completed; will prevent sewage from flowing into Lake Erie
text:
CLEVELAND, Ohio â€“ The Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District on Thursday announced the completion of the more than three-mile long Euclid Creek Tunnel, the agency's largest-ever construction project.
The tunnel is the first in a series of storage tunnels constructed as a part of Project Clean Lake , the agency's 25-year, $3 billion program to drastically reduce the amount of combined sewage entering local waterways. Construction on the Euclid Creek Tunnel started in 2011. The tunnel has a diameter of 24 feet, and will have the capacity to hold 61 million gallons of combined storm water and waste water.
The tunnel runs 190 to 220 feet below ground from Bratenahl to the sewer district's Easterly Wastewater Treatment Plant. From there, the tunnel runs under Lake Erie, passes under the shoreline at East 156th Street, and follows Lake Shore Boulevard and Nottingham Road, terminating at St. Clair Avenue.
The tunnel will become fully operational upon completion of the Tunnel Dewatering Pump Station in 2016.
The tunnel project was originally budgeted to cost $198 million, but closed Thursday at about $3.6 million under budget, according to a prepared release.
"Our engineering and construction team worked diligently to complete this project under budget," said Kellie Rotunno, the sewer district's chief operating officer.
"The Euclid Creek Tunnel sets a new financial benchmark as we continue to identify cost-savings and save our customers money."
Project Clean Lake has realized $330 million in savings since its inception, according to the district's news release. The savings are credited to value engineering, contract management and a highly competitive bidding environment.
"This tunnel system will keep hundreds of millions of gallons of combined sewage out of Lake Erie each year," said CEO Julius Ciaccia.
